results.title: Kepler and his work
results.creator_credit: Institut für Film und Bild and Education Foundation for Visual Arts
results.brief_description: Kepler’s life story, his discovery of the three Laws of Planetary Motion and work of optics. Contemporary prints illustrate his early life and education at the University of Tubingen; concepts of planetary motion held at the time, and the way Kepler’s work altered them; work in Prague leading to the Laws of Planetary Motion; study of optics, astronomical calculations and other publications; his last years, overshadowed by the Thirty Year’s War.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Institut für Film und Bild and Education Foundation for Visual Arts

results.title: Kenya: story of progress
results.creator_credit: Mercury Film Productions and Government of Kenya
results.brief_description: A survey of Kenya (1956) showing the developments taking place in all aspects of life in the territory. Illustrates agricultural and farming progress including the wheat farms, the production of maize, coffee, tea and sisal, the breeding of beef and dairy cattle. Reviews developments in transport and communications, modern health services, housing and education schemes, and the growth of industry and commerce.

results.title: Kenya today
results.creator_credit: Gordon Bradley and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: The progress made in Kenya since the Mau Mau uprisings of 1952. Kikuyu natives concentrated in villages for protection - the beginning of land consolidation and planned farming. Many Kikuyu work on large European farms growing sisal, or coffee, Kenya’s main exports. The co-existence of Africans, Indians, Arabs, and Europeans poses complex racial problems.

results.brief_description: A Digital Storytelling minidoco about the establishment and growth of the Kensington Women’s Dinner - held annually on International Women’s Day. Made as part of the ‘Pride and Diversity’ workshop in association with Vic Health.

results.title: Kensal House
results.creator_credit: Gas Light and Coke Company and Frank Sainsbury
results.brief_description: Kensal House was built by the Gas Light and Coke Company to replace slums in Kensal Green. The aim was to show that under reasonable conditions, an adequate supply of gas fuel costs no more than an inadequate supply of less efficient fuel. Conditions in the slums are shown. Then the design of the flats is explained, and its clubs, nursery school and gardens shown. The operation of Kensal House as a community is stressed.

results.title: Kennedy: years of charisma
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns International, New York Times Productions and Jeremy Murray-Brown
results.brief_description: Shows John F Kennedy’s election to the White House. Tells that in his life he was popular, drew much praise, inspired affection, and had as many critics as most politicians do, but that in death he became a hero and a legend wrapped in mythology and sentimentality. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ken's great times with Legacy
results.creator_credit: Ken Hellnig, Legacy and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Ken joined Legacy after his dad’s death. He went on the first Legacy camp in his early 20s and he shares with us his years with Legacy, the camps, day trips, boating adventures and the friends made over the years.

results.title: Kemira: diary of a strike
results.brief_description: The first Australian film to document the organisation of a strike and its unfolding over time from an “insider” perspective. In September 1982, at the height of the economic recession, Australian Iron and Steel, a subsidiary of BHP, announced its intention to retrench 400 miners from the six coal pits which supplied the company’s Wollongong steelworks. Kemira was the worst affected pit where 206 workers (two-thirds of the workforce) were to lose their jobs. A confronting account of an important historical and political event.
results.description: The first Australian film to document the organisation of a strike and its unfolding over time from an “insider” perspective. In September 1982, at the height of the economic recession, Australian Iron and Steel, a subsidiary of BHP, announced its intention to retrench 400 miners from the six coal pits which supplied the company’s Wollongong steelworks. Kemira was the worst affected pit where 206 workers (two-thirds of the workforce) were to lose their jobs. A confronting account of an important historical and political event.

results.title: Kemal: a Turkish boy
results.creator_credit: Linda Blagg, Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
Kemal is a Turkish-born youth at school in Sydney. He has been in Australia for two years. The film shows the difficulties he experiences, particularly as they relate to language. It also illustrates the cultural background of a child from Turkey which has a strong male-oriented order and where the Islam religion is dominant.
